trial_identification.studytitle: Memo multimedia mobile phone lifeskills programme for teenagers
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised controlled trial of a multimedia mobile phone programme to reduce depressive symptoms in adolescents compared to an attention control mobile phone programme

interventions.interventions: A multimedia programme delivered solely by mobile phone that has been developed by experts based on cognitive behavioural therapy. Two text/video/animated messages will be sent each day for two months, with access to the information via a mobile website for up to 12 months.
interventions.comparator: An attention control programme with the same frequency of text/video messages, animations (two messages/day for two months) & access to a mobile website (for 12 months).

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in depressive symptoms as measured by the Child Depression Rating Scale-Revised (CDRS-R).

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Self-rated depressive symptoms assessed via the Reynolds Adolescent Depression Score (RADS-2), Moods & Feelings Questionnaire
Overall functioning and quality of life assessed by the Pediatric Quality of Life Questionnaire (PQ-les-Q)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Years 9-12 at school; mobile phone capable of receiving video messages; Vodafone customer; able to provide consent
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Screening tests identify depression or risk of self-harm at baseline

trial_design.concealment: Students at participating schools invited to participate; provide informed consent; complete baseline data collection; receive run-in programme; complete assessment by Research Assistants (RA); randomised centrally by computer after RA assessment data entered.
trial_design.sequence: Computer allocation using a stratified minimisation randomisation to ensure balance for possible prognostic factors, such as sex, ethnicity (Maori/Pacific v. non-Maori/Pacific) and school.
